questions.question: 1. In a transverse wave, the particles of the medium move in what direction compared to the wave energy?
questions.explanation: In a transverse wave, particles vibrate up and down (or side-to-side) while the energy moves forward, creating a right-angle between them.

questions.question: 2. What is the name for the highest point of a transverse wave?
questions.explanation: The highest point is called the crest, like the top of an ocean wave.

questions.question: 3. What is the name for the lowest point of a transverse wave?
questions.explanation: The lowest point is called the trough.

questions.question: 4. Which of the following is the BEST example of a transverse wave you can see?
options: A wave on a shaken rope
questions.explanation: When you shake a rope up and down, you can see the crests and troughs moving along it, which is a classic transverse wave.

questions.question: 5. Which type of transverse wave can travel through empty space?
questions.explanation: Light is a transverse wave that does not need a medium. It can travel through the vacuum of space, which is why we can see the sun and stars.

questions.question: 6. What is the height of a wave, measured from its rest position to a crest, called?
questions.explanation: Amplitude is the maximum distance a particle moves from its rest position. A larger amplitude means a more energetic wave.

questions.question: 7. The distance from one wave crest to the very next crest is called the...
questions.explanation: Wavelength is the distance between two identical, successive points on a wave, such as crest-to-crest or trough-to-trough.

questions.question: 8. What property of a transverse wave is measured in hertz (Hz)?
questions.explanation: Frequency, measured in hertz (Hz), tells us how many complete waves pass a point each second.

questions.question: 9. If you increase the frequency of a wave while its speed stays the same, what happens to its wavelength?
questions.explanation: According to the wave equation (Speed = Frequency x Wavelength), if speed is constant and frequency goes up, the wavelength must get shorter (decrease).

questions.question: 10. What is the name for a transverse wave that is trapped in one vibrating plane?
questions.explanation: Polarization is a property unique to transverse waves. It means the vibrations are confined to a single plane, like light passing through polarized sunglasses.

questions.question: 11. Which of these devices uses the principle of polarization for transverse waves?
questions.explanation: Polarized sunglasses block certain planes of light vibration to reduce glare, which only works because light is a transverse wave.

questions.question: 12. Which of the following is NOT a transverse wave?
options: A wave on a guitar string
questions.explanation: Sound waves in air are longitudinal waves. The air particles vibrate back and forth in the same direction the sound is traveling, not up and down.

questions.question: 13. What does a single, sharp, up-and-down shake of a rope create?
questions.explanation: A single, quick disturbance creates a single 'bump' that travels along the rope. This is called a wave pulse.

questions.question: 14. What is the main restoring force for a transverse wave on a rope?
questions.explanation: The tension in the rope is what pulls the displaced particles back to their rest position, creating the oscillating motion.

questions.question: 15. What is the resting, flat line in the middle of a wave called?
questions.explanation: The equilibrium position is the rest position of the medium when no wave is present. Waves oscillate around this line.

questions.question: 16. Which wave would have more energy: one with a large amplitude or one with a small amplitude?
questions.explanation: A higher amplitude means the wave disturbs the medium more, which requires and carries more energy.

questions.question: 17. How are electromagnetic waves, like light and radio, classified?
questions.explanation: All electromagnetic waves are transverse waves because their electric and magnetic fields vibrate perpendicularly to the direction they travel.

questions.question: 18. What is the unit for wavelength?
questions.explanation: Wavelength is a distance, so it is measured in meters (or centimeters, nanometers, etc.).

questions.question: 19. What happens to the amplitude of a transverse wave as it travels further from its source?
questions.explanation: As a wave travels, its energy spreads out. This causes the amplitude to gradually get smaller, a process called damping.

questions.question: 20. The basic shape of a smooth, continuous transverse wave can be described as a...
questions.explanation: The smooth, repeating pattern of crests and troughs is mathematically known as a sine wave or sine curve.
